detaileddescription.para: Set this interrupt up as a zero-latency IRQ. It has a fixed hardware priority level (discarding what was supplied in the interrupt's priority argument), and will run even if irq_lock() is active. Be careful!

memberdef.name: ARCH_IRQ_CONNECT
memberdef.initializer: { \ BUILD_ASSERT(IS_ENABLED(CONFIG_ZERO_LATENCY_IRQS) || !(flags_p & IRQ_ZERO_LATENCY), \ "ZLI interrupt registered but feature is disabled"); \ _CHECK_PRIO(priority_p, flags_p) \ Z_ISR_DECLARE(irq_p, 0, isr_p, isr_param_p); \ z_arm_irq_priority_set(irq_p, priority_p, flags_p); \ }

memberdef.name: ARCH_IRQ_DIRECT_CONNECT
memberdef.initializer: { \ BUILD_ASSERT(IS_ENABLED(CONFIG_ZERO_LATENCY_IRQS) || !(flags_p & IRQ_ZERO_LATENCY), \ "ZLI interrupt registered but feature is disabled"); \ _CHECK_PRIO(priority_p, flags_p) \ Z_ISR_DECLARE(irq_p, ISR_FLAG_DIRECT, isr_p, NULL); \ z_arm_irq_priority_set(irq_p, priority_p, flags_p); \ }

memberdef.name: ARCH_ISR_DIRECT_DECLARE
memberdef.initializer: static inline int name##_body(void); \ __attribute__ ((interrupt ("IRQ"))) void name(void) \ { \ int check_reschedule; \ ISR_DIRECT_HEADER(); \ check_reschedule = name##_body(); \ ISR_DIRECT_FOOTER(check_reschedule); \ } \ static inline int name##_body(void)

detaileddescription.para: ARM AArch32-specific kernel interrupt handling interface. Included by arm/arch.h.
